header.title: A Visual Guide to Classic Tarot Cards

central_thesis: This work serves as a visual introduction to foundational cards from early Tarot decks, likely intending to educate users on their iconography and traditional meanings as part of a broader resource for understanding Tarot card divination.

structure_content.summary: Depicts a man suspended upside down by one foot, with his hands behind his back. This card traditionally symbolizes sacrifice, new perspectives, surrender, or a period of suspension and contemplation before action.

Shows a crowned figure, possibly a prince or warrior, holding a scepter, seated in a chariot pulled by two horses. This card represents triumph, willpower, control, determination, and navigating life's challenges with conviction.

Portrays a female figure holding a sword pointing upwards in one hand and a set of scales in the other, symbolizing fairness, law, truth, and balance. Above her, a knight on horseback reinforces themes of righteousness and command.

An elderly, bearded man cloaked in blue, holding a staff and a lantern, walking alone. This card signifies introspection, solitude, guidance, wisdom sought through inner reflection, and a search for truth.

Features a wheel with human figures attached to it, representing the cycles of life, change, destiny, and the fluctuating nature of fate. A winged angel figure often presides over the wheel, symbolizing divine influence or cosmic law.

Illustrates a young man (or sometimes a woman) confronting and subduing a lion, often by striking it with a club. This card embodies inner strength, courage, control over primal instincts, compassion, and fortitude.

key_concepts.definition: A deck of 78 cards, comprising 22 Major Arcana and 56 Minor Arcana, used for divination, self-exploration, and spiritual growth, with a rich history rooted in 15th-century Italy.
The 22 trump cards of a Tarot deck, representing archetypal principles, significant life lessons, and major events or influences. Each card has a distinct symbolic image and traditional meaning.

One of the oldest surviving Tarot decks, commissioned in the mid-15th century by the Dukes of Milan. It is highly valued for its historical significance and artistic merit, and its iconography heavily influenced later Tarot designs.
The practice of seeking knowledge of the future or the unknown by supernatural means, often through the interpretation of omens or signs, such as those provided by Tarot cards.

practical_system.description: The implied practical system is the use of Tarot cards for divination and self-reflection. While the book snippet itself is a visual exposition of cards, the associated website (discover-the-meaning-of-tarot.com) would presumably guide practitioners through methods of interpreting these cards in various spreads to gain insight into past, present, and future events, or to explore psychological states and spiritual paths.
tools: A complete Tarot deck (specifically, a deck featuring traditional imagery similar to the depicted Visconti-Sforza style)
A clean surface for laying out cards
Optional: a cloth or bag for storage and protection of the deck.
rituals: Drawing cards for specific questions or spreads
Laying out cards in traditional spreads (e.g., Celtic Cross, Three-Card Spread) for contextual interpretation

critical_analysis.relevance: This visual compilation is highly relevant for individuals studying the historical evolution of Tarot, providing direct imagery of early, influential cards. It serves as an accessible entry point to the visual language and archetypal symbolism that underpins much of Western esoteric thought related to Tarot, bridging academic interest with practical application.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes beginners in Tarot studies, enthusiasts of historical esoteric art, students of occult history, and individuals seeking to deepen their understanding of traditional Tarot iconography and its roots in classical Italian Renaissance culture. It is suitable for those interested in the foundational imagery before modern adaptations.
